awd_titl_txt: Pinpointing the Science of Fast Radio Bursts
awd_abstract_narration:
Bursts of radio emission from space lasting only a few thousandths of a second were first discovered in 2007.  These events, now called "fast radio bursts" (FRBs), were considered in a 2016 Nature magazine feature to be "the most perplexing mystery" in astronomy today.   Around two dozen FRBs have been detected and have been shown to come from far outside our Galaxy.  A research team led by West Virginia University (WVU) will make use of a new capability of the world's most powerful radio telescope array, NSF's Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (VLA), to detect and study several dozen FRBs over three years.  For the first time, these astronomers will be able to accurately map out the locations, distances, and environments of FRBs and identify the galaxies in which they arise.  This will allow the researchers to unequivocally find answers to fundamental questions about fast radio burst origins and use them to better understand the Universe.  The team will also directly engage thousands of high school students in the excitement and dynamism of the experiment by making it part of WVU's "Pulsar Search Collaboratory" education and outreach network.  This program will provide students access to the FRB candidates with which they can assess and discover new events and directly engage in the research and discovery process.

The WVU-based research team will use the VLA to provide arcsecond localizations of FRBs, which will, for the first time, allow their origins and nature to be studied in detail. The observations will begin to address whether the phenomenon has more than one progenitor and how FRBs can be used as tools to probe the intergalactic medium and the makeup of other galaxies. The multi-wavelength studies of FRB hosts will lay a statistically strong foundation for the future of FRB follow-up science that will endure for years into the future.  A critical component of the program will be automatic identification and public release of confident transitory events, which will open opportunities to other scientists and facilities to use the results immediately, further advancing time-domain science.

por.por_cntn:
Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are among the most enigmatic of cosmic mysteries currently being studied in astronomy. They are intense flashes of radio light that last only milliseconds. First discovered in 2007, scientists were unsure for the first decade after their discovery as to whether the bursts were even of cosmic origin (they were even thought to potentially arise from microwave ovens!). The initial difficulty with the exact identification of the origins of the bursts were because telescope systems were not able to localize them.

Our project's primary goal was to adapt the data processing at the Karl G. Janksy Very Large Array in New Mexico to be able to make images at an extremely fast rate, allowing us to "piggyback" on other experiments, and search for FRBs whenever the telescope observed. The Very Large Array is an interferometer, which is a telescope that can take high-precision images. With fast-sampling power and excellent localization of FRBs, this system would be a key tool for localizing and studying the environments of FRBs. We called this system "Realfast" - it was searching in real-time for fast transients.

It is also worth noting that FRBs can be used to probe the diffuse, otherwise invisible material that sits between galaxies. We call this the "intergalactic medium", and it is the material that is thought to make up the "missing matter" in the universe; it's "missing" because if you add up all of the light and material we can see, it doesn't account for all of the mass and material we know is out there from studies of the evolution of the universe. Localized FRBs can form a great probe of this diffuse medium because the radio light interacts with it on its way to Earth, providing us with observable consequences of that interaction.

Over the course of this program, we performed the first localization of an FRB (FRB121102), pinning it down to a tiny dwarf galaxy, and to a region whose only other emission was optical light from ambient star formation and a persistent radio source. 

Each subsequent FRB seems to come with a further surprise. With further detections that we and others localized to host galaxies, we found that FRB121102 was unique in its environment. In fact, FRBs are hosted by many types of galaxies, and the FRBs seem to lie across cosmic time; some appear to be embedded in star-forming regions, some exist in merging galaxies, and others lie at the quiet edges of single-galaxy systems.

Various theories have been proposed to explain the origins of FRBs, ranging from cosmic collisions to powerful neutron stars or even advanced extraterrestrial civilizations trying to communicate with us. While we still don't have a definitive answer, Realfast has provided a set of burst with which to study in detail the local material and varied environments that give rise to FRBs. With each new unique burst localized, we get one step closer in determining what gives rise to these extreme sources of energy.

Image credit: Danielle Futselaar
